questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has pain in her fingers on exposure to cold, arthralgias, and difficulty swallowing solid food. On examination thickening of the skin over the hands, arms, and trunk is present. What is the best diagnostic workup?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Antinuclear, anti-Scl-70, and anticentromere antibodies 
The symptoms of Raynaud phenomenon, arthralgia, and dysphagia point towardthe diagnosis of scleroderma. 
Antinuclear antibodies are most sensitive but non-specific.
Anti-Scl-70 (also known as anti-topoisomerase-1) antibody are less sensitive but highly specific. 
Anti-centromere antibodies are positive in limited disease.
Rheumatoid factor is nonspecific and present in 20% of patients with scleroderma. 
Elevated CK and anti-Jo-1 antibodies are present in an inflammatory myositis such as polymyositis.

The child has had a few upper respiratory infections and ear infections, but her history is otherwise unremarkable. The family has not vaccinated any of their children due to religious objections. The child’s temperature is 102°F. Physical exam reveals a positive Brudzinski’s sign. 1. Poly saccharide capsule, 
2. Gram negative diplococci, 
3.Satellitism, 
4. Polysaccharide vaccine for this patient
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
1,3 are correct
•	It’s a case of Meningitis due to Hemophilusinfluenzae.
•	Its Gram negative bacilli.
•	Polysaccharide capsule present.
•	Exhibits satellitism in blood agar.
•	Factor X and V are the growth factors.
•	Children less than 2 years needed conjugate vaccine

questions.text: A 26 years old G2P1L1 with 39 weeks of gestation and cephalic presentation has labour pains since 6 hours. On examination, the uterus is corresponding to period of gestation, FHS are normal, head is engaged, cervical dilatation is 2 cm and membranes are intact. On repeat examination after 4 hours, the findings were same but uterine contractions had increased from one contraction per 10 minutes to 2 contractions in 10 minutes, each contraction lasting for 10 seconds. What should be the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
give sedation and watch for progress of labour
This patient is in latent phase of labour. There is no indication of expediting the process of labour since all her parameters are normal. We must give sedation and pain relief and watch for progress of labour. Partogram is plotted once she goes in active phase of labour.
William’s obstetrics, 25th edition, chapter 22, normal labour, management.

questions.text:
A 60 years old male patient presented with non specific loin pain for which he was undertaken CT abdomen and pelvis. On the basis of the image provided which of the following is appropriate step in management?
Size of the cyst 4x4cm.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Surgery 
The Bosniak classification of renal cystic masses is as outlined:
I : Simple benign cysts with hairline thin walls. The cysts do not contain septations, calcifications or solid components. There are no enhancing soft tissue components.
II: Benign cystic lesions. The cysts may have hairline thin septations with fine calcifications in the walls. Minimal enhancement of the hairline thin smooth wall may be seen. No enhancing soft tissue components are present. Non-enhancing high-attentuation cysts <3 cm in size are included.
IIF : Complex cysts requiring follow-up imaging. These cyst are more complex and do not fit into category II or III. These cysts have an increased number of hairline septations
or mild thickening of the wall and/or septations. No enhancing soft tissue components are present. 
III: Indeterminate masses. The cystic lesions have thickened walls and septations that are irregular. The cyst walls or septations demonstrate enhancement.
IV: Malignant cystic masses. Thick and irregular walls and septations may be present but enhancing soft tissue components are seen, independent of wall or septal enhancement.

questions.text: A 35 years old G3P1A1L1 with 30 weeks of gestation with twin gestation has discordance in the weight of the twins. There is oligohydramnios in one sac and polyhydramnios in another sac. The bladder of the small baby is not visible. There is no abnormality of umbilical artery doppler flow study yet. Which is this STAGE of Quintero classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
stage 2
Stage I—discordant amnionic fluid volumes as described in the earlier paragraph, but urine is still visible sonographically within the bladder of the donor twin
• Stage II—criteria of stage I, but urine is not visible within the donor bladder
• Stage III—criteria of stage II and abnormal Doppler studies of the umbilical artery, ductus venosus, or umbilical vein
• Stage IV—ascites or frank hydrops in either twin
• Stage V—demise of either foetus.
William’s obstetrics 25th edition page no 1952 (e-book)

questions.text: A 50 -year-old man presented with fever, cough, sputum, right-sided pleuritic chest pain and dyspnea. Chest x-ray reveals a consolidation right lower zone and CBC shows an elevated neutrophil count. Which feature would most strongly support inpatient admission for management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Respiratory rate of 36/min
The CURB-65 score is used for determining if inpatient admission is indicated. Factors predicting increased severity of infection include confusion, urea > 7 mmol/L, respiratory rate above 30, BP below 90 systolic (or 60 diastolic), and age 65 or above. If more than one of these factors is present, hospitalization should be considered.

questions.text: A 57 years old multiparous patient has postmenopausal bleeding since 3 months. Which of the following is the next best line of investigation to rule out endometrial cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
transvaginal sonography 
ACOG UPDATE
The clinical approach to postmenopausal bleeding requires prompt and efficient evaluation to exclude or diagnose endometrial carcinoma and endometrial intraepithelial neoplasia. Transvaginal ultrasonography usually is sufficient for an initial evaluation of postmenopausal bleeding if the ultrasound images reveal a thin endometrial echo (less than or equal to 4 mm), given that an endometrial thickness of 4 mm or less has a greater than 99% negative predictive value for endometrial cancer. Transvaginal ultrasonography is a reasonable alternative to endometrial sampling as a first approach in evaluating a postmenopausal woman with an initial episode of bleeding

questions.text: 24  years old ramesh presents with pain over the bridge of the nose. It was aggravated by movements of eyeballs.Examination revealed oedema of both eyelids and swelling of the middle turbinate. Involvement of which of the following para-nasal sinus is suspected.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Ethmoid  Sinus
Sol:
When the mucosal lining (sinus mucosa) of the ethmoid sinuses develops inflammation, it results in swelling (edema) of the mucosa. Considering that ostia (conduit that drains ethmoid sinuses into the nose) is very small in diameter to start with, inflammation/swelling of the mucosa causes the blockage of the ostia. Reduction in the flow of the mucociliary drainage causes the mucus content to accumulate within the ethmoid sinuses. Build up of mucosal secretions within the sinuses eventually results in an infection -a condition known as Ethmoid Sinusitis or Ethmoiditis.
Symptoms of ethmoid sinusitis often includes:
•	Headache in the temples,
•	Pain in the lower forehead,
•	Stuffy/Runny nose, 
•	Breathing difficulties,
•	Sinus pain and/or sinus pressure around the inner corners of the eyes,
•	Worsening of the symptoms while lying on the back and improvement of the same while the head in upright position.

questions.text:
The fetus lives in a relatively hypoxemic environment. The intrauterine circulation consists of two parallel systems that are not completely separated because of mixing at the atrial and ductal level.
The following vessels/chambers have oxygen saturations from HIGHEST to LOWEST:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Umbilical vein> left ventricle > right ventricle > superior vein cava 
The oxygen saturations in a human fetus are estimated from studies in fetal lambs during late gestation. After mixing of oxygenated maternal blood with fetal deoxygenated blood in the spaces surrounding the placental villi, oxygen is transported into the numerous villi and flows into the umbilical vein. The umbilical vein has the highest oxygen saturation of the fetus (70%). The superior vein cava has the lowest oxygen content of the fetus because of high oxygen extraction by the brain (estimated oxygen saturation=40%). Blood from the umbilical vein, inferior vein cava, and superior vein cava returns to the right atrium and right ventricle leading to a combined oxygen saturation of approximately 55%. Blood in the left atrium is a mixture of blood entering from the umbilical vein and crossing the right atrium through the foramen ovale (70% oxygen saturation), as well as a small amount of blood returning from the fetal pulmonary circulation (55% oxygen saturation). Thus, the oxygen saturations on the left side of the heart tend to be higher than the right-sided chambers. The estimated intrauterine oxygen saturations in humans

questions.text: Which of these is not an essential amino acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Homocysteine
	An essential amino acid or indispensable amino acid, is an amino acid that cannot be synthesized de novo by humans, and therefore must be supplied in the diet. 
	Essential amino acids are: histidine, isoleucine, leucine, lysine, methionine, phenylalanine, threonine, tryptophan, and valine. 
In addition, the amino acids arginine, cysteine, glycine and tyrosine are considered conditionally essential, meaning they are not normally required in the diet, but must be supplied exogenously to specific populations that do not synthesize it in adequate amounts.

questions.text:
A 20 year old male presented to the clinic with history of fever with chills for past 2 days. He complained of associated headache and myalgia. The highest recorded temperature at home was 41֯ C and there was no particular pattern. Patient is case of Hereditary Spherocytosis and underwent Splenectomy for the same at 12 years of age since he was transfusion dependant. His vaccination history is complete. On examination he had a Temperature of 40֯ C, P-90/min, BP-100/60mm of Hg. He had pallor and icterus with no lymphadenopathy. 
Laboratory tests revealed a Hb-7.3gm/dl, WBC-4600, Plt-94000.His Liver function test showed an elevated bilirubin with elevated ALP, SGOT, SGPT. Urine analysis showed haemoglobinuria and proteinuria.Examination of Giemsa-stained thin smear revealed ameboidtrophozoites lacking hemozoin deposits. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Babesiosis
Babesiosis is a malaria-like parasitic disease transmitted by tick bites (most commonly) or after receiving blood products from an infected donor. Half of healthy adults with Babesia infection are asymptomatic. When people do develop symptoms, the most common are fever and hemolyticanemia, symptoms that are similar to those of malaria. In more severe cases, symptoms similar to malaria occur, with fevers up to 40.5 °C (105 °F), shaking chills, and severe anemia (hemolyticanemia). Organ failure may follow, including adult respiratory distress syndrome. Sepsis in people who have had a splenectomy can occur rapidly, consistent with overwhelming post-splenectomy infection. Severe cases are also more likely to occur in the very young, very old, and persons with immunodeficiency, such as HIV/AIDS patients.
The smear shows hemozoin deficient trophozoites and is diagnostic.  In mild-to-moderate babesiosis, the treatment of choice is a combination of atovaquone and azithromycin. The standard course is 7 to 10 days, but this is extended to at least 6 weeks in people with relapsing disease. In severe babesiosis, the combination of clindamycin and quinine is preferred. In life-threatening cases, exchange transfusion is performed.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man presents with duodenal peptic ulcer and complains of cramping epigastric pain. Which of the following structures harbors the cell bodies of abdominal pain fibers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Dorsal root ganglion
Sol:   
• Cell bodies of the abdominal pain fibers are located in the dorsal root ganglion. The lateral horn of the spinal cord contains cell bodies of sympathetic preganglionic nerve fibers; the anterior horn contains cell bodies of general somatic efferent (GSE) fibers.
• The sympathetic chain ganglion contains cell bodies of sympathetic postganglionic fibers, which supply blood vessels, sweat glands, and hair follicles.
• The celiac ganglion contains cell bodies of sympathetic postganglionic fibers, which supply the visceral organs such as stomach and intestine.

A chest radiograph demonstrates a cavity infiltrate of the right upper lobe. Choose the method(s) from the list would best confirm the identity of the most likely pathogen of this infection?
1. Ziehl – Neelsen stain,
2. Auramine – Rhodamine stain, 
3. Acridine orange stain, 
4. Auramine O Phenol stain
questions.solution:

1,2,4 are correct.
•	It’s a case of Pulmonary tuberculosis caused by mycobacterium tuberculosis.
•	Staining methods are ZiehlNeelsen staining and fluorescent stains are Auramine-Rhodamine and Auramine O phenol staining.
•	Acridine orange is for Plasmodium.

questions.text:
Assertion: Following large volume paracentesis more than 5 litres, intravenous albumin infusion is given
Reason: intravenous albumin minimises intravascular depletion
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Large-volume paracentesis, in which more than 5 liters of ascites fluid is removed from the peritoneal cavity, may be useful for patients with ascites that has been unresponsive to sodium restriction and diuretic treatment; this occurs in less than 10% of patients. The intravenous infusion of albumin (6 to 8 g/liter of ascitic fluid removed) at the time of paracentesis will minimize the symptoms of intravascular volume depletion and renal insufficiency, which may accompany the removal of more than 5 liters of ascitic fluid.

questions.text: A patient involved in a road traffic accident is brought to the surgery emergency with shortness of breath. HRCT was done. A 3-D reconstruction of the CT is shown. True about this condition are all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
This condition usually results from blunt trauma associated with multiple rib fractures, and is defined as two or more ribs fractured in two or more places. The blunt force typically also produces an underlying pulmonary contusion. To confirm the diagnosis the chest wall can be observed for paradoxical motion of a chest wall segment. On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall is displaced inwards and therefore less air moves into the lungs. On expiration, the segment moves outwards (paradoxical respiration). Currently, treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates) and physiotherapy. If a chest tube is in situ, topical intrapleural local analgesia introduced via the tube, can also be used. Ventilation(IPPV)is reserved for cases developing respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

questions.text: A child who is eating round candies approximately 1.5 cm in diameter inhales one down his airway blocking the left main bronchus. Which of the following set of changes will be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

↑ left lung alveolar Pco2, ↓ left lung alveolar Po2, ↓ systemic arterial Po2

Blockage of the left main bronchus results in no movement of fresh air into the left lung. Therefore, the air in the alveoli of the left lung equilibrates with the pulmonary arterial blood. Therefore, the Po2 will decrease from 100 to 40 mm Hg, Pco2 will increase from 40 to 45 mm Hg, and the systemic Po2 will decrease because there is decreased O2 uptake from the alveoli and thus decreased O2 diffusion from the alveoli.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman presents with bilateral conductive deafness, palpable purpura on the legs and hemoptysis. Radiograph of the chest shows a cavity in left lower zone. Investigations reveal total leukocyte count 12000/mm, red cell casts in the urine and 12,000/mm3 serum creatinine 3 mg/dL. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Wegener's granulomatosis.
Wegener's granulomatosis is a distinct clinicopathologic entity characterized by granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tracts together with glomerulonephritis. 
Upper respiratory tract- Nasal mucosal ulceration, Nasal septal perforation, Saddle nose deformity, Serous otitis media 
Pulmonary involvement- cough, hemoptysis, pulmonary infiltrates or cavity 
Eye involvement-conjunctivitis, dacryocystitis, episcleritis, scleritis, granulomatous sclerouveitis, 
Renal disease- glomerulitis with proteinuria, hematuria, and red blood cell casts

In typical Wegener's granulomatosis with granulomatous vasculitis of the respiratory tract and glomerulonephritis, approximately 90% of patients have a positive c-ANCA. However, in the absence of renal disease, the sensitivity drops to approximately 70%.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The patient’s history, signs, and symptoms suggest that she was most likely suffering from propylthiouracil-induced toxic hepatitis. More than 900 drugs have been implicated in causing liver injury, but propylthiouracil, isoniazid, halo- thane, valproate, and certain antipyretics (acetaminophen, diclofenac, and indomethacin) are among the drugs most frequently involved in acute hepatocellular toxicity. Prop- ylthiouracil-induced toxic hepatitis occurs in about 1% of treated patients, is always severe, and can be lethal. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has added a black box warn- ing to the label of propylthiouracil. 
A Methimazole-induced liver injury is extremely rare. In addition, propylthiouracil is preferred over methimazole in the first trimester of pregnancy because it crosses the pla- centa much less than methimazole. 
B, D,  Liver injury with these drugs is negligible.

questions.text: A 28 year old sustained a laceration on his leg, which was sutured under local anaesthesia in minor OT. He followed up for dressing every third day and got dressed by the nurse. On Day 8 he complains of fever, the surgeon looks at the wound there is a suppurative exudate from the wound, a culture shows staphylococcus aureus. Which of the following would have best prevented such an infection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Proper washing hands by the nurse before dressing. Methicillin resistant Staphylococcus aureus a commensal in the skin of healthy individuals can cause infection in the wounds, thus washing hands properly before dressing is the best way to prevent this infection.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy was admitted to the emergency department after a generalized tonic-colonic seizure. His mother reported that the boy apparently ingested several tablets of propranolol, a β-blocker, which he had found in his father’s dresser drawer. Vital signs on admission were blood pressure 85/50 mm Hg, heart rate 40 beats per minute (bpm), respiratory rate 20/min. The boy received an intramuscular injection of glucagon, a hormone that activates glucagon receptors in the heart, caus- ing a significant increase in heart contractility. Which of the following terms best defines the antagonism between gluca- gon and β-blockers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Glucagon is sometimes used to treat β-blocker overdose. By blocking β1 receptors in the heart, β-blockers lead to a dose- dependent decrease in heart contractility. Glucagon-induced activation of glucagon receptors leads to an increase in heart contractility. When a drug response mediated by the acti- vation of a receptor is antagonized by an opposite response produced by another drug acting on a different set of recep- tors, the antagonism is defined as functional (also called physiologic).

questions.text: Which of the following is the pre trematic nerve of first pharyngeal arch?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
 Chorda tympani

  • The mandibular and maxillary branches of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) innervate the structures derived from the corresponding processes of the first arch. 
  • The nerve of the arch itself runs along the cranial side of the arch and is called post-trematic nerve of the arch.
  • Each arch also receives a branch from the nerve of the succeeding arch called thepretrematic nerve which runs along the caudal border of the arch.
  •  In human embryo, a double innervation is seen only in the first pharyngeal arch.
  • The mandibular nerve is the post-trematic nerve of the first arch and chorda tympani (branch of facial nerve) is thepretrematic nerve.
  • This double innervation is reflected in the nerve supply of anterior two-thirds of tongue which is derived from the first arch.

questions.text: Preoperative skin preparation is ideally done at:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The preoperative preparation of the skin is concerned chiefly with mechanical cleansing. It is important that the patient’s skin be prepared(preferably clippers) immediately before operation; preferably in the operating suite after anesthetization.
This eliminates discomfort to the patient, affords relaxation of the operative site, and is a bacteriologically sound technique. There should be as short a time lapse as possible between skin preparation and incision, thus preventing contamination of the site by a regrowth of organisms or the possibility of a nick or scratch presenting a source of infection. The skin is held taut to present an even, smooth surface as the hair is removed with power-driven disposable clippers. The use of sharp razors to remove hair is discouraged

questions.text: A 69-year-old man was recently diagnosed with severe car- diac failure, and the physician started treatment with pro- pranolol, captopril, and digoxin. Diuretic therapy was also included. Which of the following pairs of diuretics would have been most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The majority of patients with cardiac failure will require the chronic administration of a loop diuretic to maintain euvolemia. However, these drugs cause hypokalemia, which increases the risk of adverse effects with cardiac glycosides. In fact, a decrease in serum K+ concentration increases the binding of cardiac glycosides to Na+/K+ ATPase. The con- current administration of potassium-sparing diuretics such as spironolactone will prevent furosemide-induced hypo- kalemia. 
B Potassium-sparing diuretics have low diuretic efficacy and therefore are not suitable for treating a patient with car- diac failure. 
C, D Mannitol is absolutely contraindicated in heart failure because the resulting extracellular volume expansion can cause a dangerous circulatory overload.

questions.text: A 20 year girl is worried that she might develop a cancer after seeing a documentary on familial breast cancer on TV. Her mother developed left breast cancer at the age of 30 years which was treated with mastectomy and axillary clearance, six years later she developed carcinoma of right breast for which similar treatment was done. Later she died of metastatic breast carcinoma. Which of the following information is least helpful in making a suspicion of familial breast carcinoma in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Her mother’s tumor cells showing BRCA 1 mutation. Tumor cells showing mutation can be either sporadic or inherited thus won’t help us to differentiate between the two. If BRCA mutation is seen in non tumor cells it is diagnostic of inherited mutation. Pancreatic carcinoma could be due to inherited BRCA mutations (both 1 &2), inherited cancers are most likely to be multifocal and bilateral due to first hit being present in all cells. And because of the same reason familial carcinomas occur early in life as compared to sporadic.

questions.text: The  Homans operation done for lymphedema involves:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
In the Homans operation, skin flaps are elevated, and then subcutaneous tissue is excised from beneath the flaps, which are then trimmed to size to accommodate the reduced girth of the limb and closed primarily. This is the most satisfactory operation for the calf. The main complication is skin flap necrosis. There must be at least 6 months between operations on the medial and lateral sides of the limb and the flaps must not pass the midline.

Copper transport disrupted in Wilson’s disease.
Menkes’ kinky-hair syndrome is an X-linked metabolic disturbance of copper metabolism characterized by mental retardation, severe neurological degeneration leading to fatal outcome in early childhood. Lab investigations include hypocupremia and decreased circulating ceruloplasmin, neutropenia and anemia. 
Chronic copper intoxication causes Indian childhood cirrhosis. 
Keshan disease is an endemic cardiomyopathy found in children and young women.

questions.text: A 24 years old G2P1L1 with 36 weeks of gestation has developed hypertension of 144/96 mm of Hg (recorded twice). Her urine albumin is 3+. She has no other symptoms but USG is suggestive of reduced diastolic flow in umbilical artery with S/D ratio of 4.2. The amniotic fluid index is 6cm. she is not in labour. Foetal weight is 15th percentile of the gestational age. She is admitted in hospital for further evaluation and investigations. Her investigations have come within normal range. What should be the plan of action in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Continue pregnancy till 37 weeks
This patient has pre-eclampsia without severe features. There is utero placental insufficiency but the diastolic blood flow is present (S/D is 4.2). baby weight is falling in the normal range so there is no IUGR and oligohydramnios. In such cases we must continue pregnancy till 37 weeks. Anti-hypertensives are indicated only when the BP reaches 150/100mm Hg.

questions.text:
An 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician by his father with a 2-day history of swelling in his hands and ankles and blood in his urine. The father states that about 2 weeks ago the boy had been sick with fever and complaining of a sore throat. They didn’t visit the doctor at that time because the boy felt better after 2 days without antimicrobial treatment. The boy’s temperature is 98.8°F and his blood pressure is 210/140 mm Hg. Physical demonstrates significant edema of the hands, wrists, feet, and ankles. A urine specimen is collected and results are given below:
• Urinalysis–Dipstick
– Blood: positive
– Protein: positive
– Leukocyte esterase: negative
– Nitrite: negative
 Choose the structure(s) most likely directly involved in the development of the boy’s current condition?
1. Antigen-antibody complex,

2. β-Hemolysin,

3. M protein,

4.Superantigen
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
1 is correct
•	This is a case of poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis. Streptococcus pyogenes (also called group A streptococci or GAS), a gram-positive coccus in chains, is a causative agent of pharyngitis. 
•	If untreated, pharyngitis lasts about 1 week or less. However, postinfectious conditions such as glomerulonephritis or rheumatic fever may occur approximately 1 to 3 weeks after the pharyngitis. 
•	Antibodies to GAS are made during pharyngitis and these antigen-antibody immune complexes are then deposited in the glomerular basement membrane. 
•	Complement is activated, which induces inﬂammation. 
•	Typical symptoms of poststreptococcus glomerulonephritis in children include edema, hematuria, and hypertension. Glomerulonephritis and rheumatic fever may also arise, following untreated GAS skin infections. 
•	Note that the mechanism of rheumatic fever is due to cross-reactive antibodies rather than antibody-antigen complex deposition

questions.text: A 78-year-old man was admitted to the hospital because of dyspnea, a nonproductive cough, and fever. The man had been receiving an antiarrhythmic drug for 2 months to treat refractory supraventricular tachycardia. A chest x-ray showed diffuse bilateral infiltrates. Bacterial, fungal, and viral cultures were negative. Which of the following drugs most likely caused the patient’s pulmonary disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The patient’s signs and symptoms indicate a pulmonary disorder. Microbial infection is unlikely, and diffuse bilat- eral lung infiltrates are consistent with pulmonary fibrosis. Amiodarone-induced pulmonary fibrosis is the most serious adverse effect of the drug. Its incidence is variable (1 to 7% of the population), and mortality is also quite variable (0.1 to 10.0% of those affected). Amiodarone toxicity is cumulative and is more common in elderly patients, as in this case. 
A, B, D,  All of the other listed drugs may be used for prophylaxis of sustained ventricular tachycardia, but they do not cause pulmonary fibrosis.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman was in the emergency department for the treatment of shock due to spinal trauma. Despite fluid therapy, she was still hypotensive (80/50 mm Hg) and tachy- cardic (125 bpm). An intravenous infusion of norepineph- rine was started, and a few minutes later the blood pressure was 120/85 mm Hg, and the heart rate decreased to 85 bpm. Which of the following actions best explains the drug- induced decrease of heart rate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Norepinephrine usually causes a reflex bradycardia in pa- tients with intact innervation of the heart for the following reason: the increase in blood pressure due to activation of α1 receptors activates baroreceptors located in the carotid sinus and aortic arch (baroreceptors are stretch receptors). This increases the firing rate to the nucleus of the tractus soli- tarius in the medulla, which in turn increases its firing to the vagal motor neurons (dorsal motor neuron and nucleus am- biguus). When this vagal excitation is strong enough, it can overcome the norepinephrine-induced tachycardia due to ac- tivation of cardiac β receptors; therefore, bradycardia ensues. 
A, B These actions would cause an increase, not a decrease, in heart rate. 
E Decreased firing rate of carotid chemoreceptors occurs only in severe pathologic conditions and would cause an in- crease, not a decrease, in heart rate.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman suffering from open-angle glaucoma had been receiving topical timolol for 3 months. The disease was well controlled, and the treatment stopped the progres- sion of optic nerve damage. Which of the following molecu- lar actions most likely mediated the therapeutic efficacy of the drug in the patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Timolol is a nonselective β-receptor blocker. Activation of all β receptors increases the synthesis of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) through increased activity of the adenylate cyclase enzyme. By blocking these receptors, all β-blockers do the opposite (i.e., the activity of adenylate cyclase is decreased).

Several superﬁcial ulcers are present on the buccal mucosa and soft palate; the tonsils appear normal and do not have exudate. Skin examination ﬁndings are shown in the image. The infectious agent most likely responsible for this patient's current condition is also associated with which of the following ?
1. Myocarditis,

4. BornHolm disease

questions.text: A 78-year-old man from a nursing home was admitted to the emergency department because of a change in his mental state over the past few hours. He had a medical history of angina and hypertension presently treated with isosorbide mononitrate, losartan, and hydrochlorothiazide. Physical ex- amination showed a person with decreased skin turgor and disorientation to time and place without focal neurologic deficits. Blood pressure was 110/65 mm Hg on standing and 140/88 mm Hg on lying. Pertinent blood tests on admission were Na+ 116 mEq/L (normal 136−145 mEq/L); K+ 3.1 mEq/L (normal 3.5−5.0 mEq/L); uric acid 10.2 mg/dL (normal 3.0− 8.2 mg/dL); creatinine 3.1 mg/dL (normal 0.6−1.2 mg/dL). The physician thought that the syndrome was due to diuretic therapy. Which of the following drug-induced adverse effects most likely caused the patient’s signs and symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The patient’s signs and symptoms suggest the diagnosis of hypovolemic hyponatremia, which is a rare but sometimes fatal adverse effect of thiazide diuretics. These drugs affect the diluting ability of the kidney while increasing Na+ excre- tion. Once volume depletion occurs, the release of antidiuretic hormone causes water retention and worsens hyponatre- mia. This effect of thiazides may last 1 to 2 weeks after ces- sation of the therapy. Elderly patients are especially prone to thiazide-induced hyponatremia, particularly if preexisting renal insufficiency exists, as in this case (see the high creati- nine level). 
A, B, D These disorders do not cause the signs and symp- toms shown by the patient.

questions.text: Ideal dose of mannitol administered to control increased ICP is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Mannitol is administered in a dose of 0.25 to 1 g/kg every 4 to 6 hours. Serum osmolality is followed closely when mannitol is being given, and the drug is withheld if serum osmolality exceeds 320 mOsm/kg. 
Elevating head of bed to improve venous drainage. Oxygenation and ventilation to keep PaO2 >100, PaCO2 30-35, use lowest possible AW pressures to not impede venous drainage, and keep MAP at pre-intubation level. Mannitol decreases blood viscosity, CBF unchanged while CBV and ICP decrease. Mannitol also reduces ICP by reducing cerebral parenchymal cell water, total effect takes 20-30min. Eventually Mannitol enters CSF and increases ICP. 3% Saline has similar osmotic effect as Mannitol. Other benefits include enhancement of cardiac output, reduction of inflammation, restoration of normal cellular resting membrane potential and cell volume, and stimulation of the release of atrial natriuretic peptide. NMB reduces ICP by avoiding coughing. Lidocaine can also blunt airway response and avoid increasing ICP w/ intubation. Sedation decreases anxiety, fear, and response to pain, all of which increase ICP. Steroids can reduce edema, especially in traumatic brain injury – steroids are harmful in the setting of TBI but may be exceedingly helpful in patients with intracranial tumors.

questions.text:
You are called to the delivery room to evaluate a full-term male infant who has just been born by vaginal birth. You observe that the infant is in severe respiratory distress without breath sounds on the left side. The infant's abdomen is scaphoid in appearance. 
What is the most appropriate initial management of this infant?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Intubate the infant and minimize inflation pressure to achieve gentle ventilation 
The infant described in this vignette has clinical signs of a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH). Affected infants have herniation of their intestines (as well as possibly stomach, spleen and liver) through the diaphragm as a result of failure of the closure of the pleuroperitoneal canal at approximately 8 weeks' gestation Clinically, affected infants have respiratory distress, a scaphoid abdomen, absence of breath sounds on the affected side or bowel sounds on the affected side, and shifted heart sounds that may be heard best on the opposite side of the herniated contents. The respiratory management of infants with CDH involves a gentle ventilation approach, which has been shown to improve survival. Inflation pressures should be minimized with tolerance of hypercapnia and relative post-ductal hypoxemia. 
The insertion of a chest tube to evacuate air from the pleural space is the management of an infant with a pnetunothorax. Although infants with pneumothoraces will also demonstrate absence of breath sounds on the affected side, they will not have a scaphoid abdomen. 
An infant with lung atelectasis will have diminished breath sounds on the affected side but will not have a scaphoid abdomen Affected infants can be treated with bag-mask ventilation with high positive inspiratory pressure to reinflate the collapsed lung. Infants with ductal-dependent congenital heart defects typically demonstrate cyanosis with a lack of respiratory distress and do not exhibit a scaphoid abdomen; treatment with intravenous prostaglandin is required.

questions.text: The assimilation of fats include (1) secretion of chylomicrons (2) micelle formation (3) absorption of fats by the enterocytes (4) emulsification of fats. Which of the following correctly describes the sequence of events?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
4, 2, 3, 1
Fat entering the small intestine is first emulsified into smaller globules by bile released from the gall bladder. 
Pancreatic lipase in conjunction with co-lipase then digests the fts (which is mostly triglycerides) into monoglycerides and free fatty acids; these substances then become surrounded by bile salts to form water-soluble aggregates called micelles.
When a micelle makes contact with an enterocyte, the monoglycerides and free fatty acids diffuse directly into the interior of the enterocytes. 
Once inside the enterocytes, re-esterification of fats takes place resulting in the formation of chylomicrons. The chylomicrons are exocytosed at the basolateral membrane of the enterocyte to enter into a lymphatic capillary (central lacteal) in the villus.

questions.text: Mr. Tandon had an ECG at a local clinic, but he misplaced the ECG record soon after. The ECG technician remembers that the QRS deflection was large and positive in lead II and 0 in aVL. What is his mean electrical axis in the frontal plane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
+60 degrees
The patient has a mean electrical axis of +60 degrees because of large and positive deflection in lead II and 0 deflection in aVL. The axis of lead II is +60 degrees and aVL is -30 degrees (which is perpendicular to lead II), and this indicates that the mean electrical axis is +60 degrees.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man had to undergo surgery to remove a bili- ary calculus. The anesthesiologist chose to supplement the anesthesia with succinylcholine, a paralyzing agent that has a rapid onset and a short duration of action. In this patient, however, the drug-induced paralysis lasted several hours, ne- cessitating the anesthesiologist to continue the anesthesia and continue artificial respiration. Which of the following adverse drug reactions best explains the patient’s disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
An idiosyncratic reaction is commonly defined as a ge- netically determined abnormal reaction to a drug. Succinyl- choline and mivacurium are neuromuscular blocking drugs that are primarily metabolized by plasma cholinesterase (butyrylcholinesterase). Because of this extensive and rapid metabolism, the action of these drugs is brief. The neuro- muscular blockade by these drugs may be exceedingly pro- longed in patients who have a genetically abnormal variant of cholinesterase. Also, because this variant is much less effi- cient than the normal enzyme, it can take 2 to 3 hours for the paralysis to disappear. In this case, the anesthesiologist must continue the general anesthesia and artificial respira- tion until cessation of the drug effect.

questions.text: A 8-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric emergency room due to sudden onset of facial swelling 2 hours ago. He has had no itching or pain other than a sore throat over the past 2 days, for which he has taken acetaminophen. The patient has had similar episodes of facial swelling that resolved spontaneously after a few days. On examination, his temperature is 370 C, blood pressure is 100/78 mm Hg, pulse is 95/min, and respirations are 24/min. He completed all the childhood vaccinations. Examination shows nonpitting edema of the cheeks, lips, and tongue; there is no tenderness or erythema. The appearance of his face is shown in the image. All other systems examination findings are  are normal. The clinician suspected this condition is due to some immunological disorder and he ordered the tests. Based the history and physical examination findings, Which of the following studies is most likely to be abnormal in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Serum C4 level
•	This patient's recurrent facial swelling is most likely due to hereditary angioedema, which is characterizedby a deficiency or dysfunction of C1 inhibitor (previously referred to as C1 esterase inhibitor). 
•	Poor C1 inhibitor function leads to elevated bradykinin, a peptide that causes vasodilation and increased vascularpermeability, resulting in edema.
•	Presentation is typically in childhood or adolescence with episodes of swelling affecting the skin (eg, face, extremities) and mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract and larynx. Attacks are often precipitated by minor trauma (eg, dental procedure) or emotional stress and are not associated with itching, tenderness, rash,or classic medication triggers (eg, ACE inhibitors, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs).
•	Initial evaluation of hereditary angioedema is with complement testing. Low C4 is characteristic because, in the absence of C1 inhibitor, unregulated activation of C1 leads to excess activated C1 and, in turn unchecked cleavage of C4. Diagnosis is confirmed by a decrease in functional C1 inhibitor level.

Swyer syndrome is a case of pure gonadal dysgenesis. The karyotype is 46XY but there are streak gonads. Since androgens are not produced, the baby has female external genitalia. The other options given in the question cause ambiguous genitalia at birth.
WILLIAM’S GYNECOLOGY, CHAPTER 16 AMENORRHOEA, DISORDERS OF SEXUAL DEVELOPMENT

questions.text: The image depicts the phenomenon of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
  – Lead Time Bias
As is evident from the image despite early diagnosis there is no benefit to the patient.
•	Lead time: advantage gained by screening i.e, early detection of disease ensures earlier initiation of treatment
•	Screening time: of no use if applied after a final critical point
•	Lead Time Bias: occurs when the screening test advances the time of diagnosis, but no true prolongation of life occurs because survival for women who are screened & those who are not is the same from the time the cancer occurs
•	Length bias: Rapidly progressive cancers will be less likely to be detected by a screening test if symptoms rapidly develop because the window period between the time the cancer can be detected when it is asymptomatic by a screening test and the time it will become clinically apparent is short. This is described as length bias. 
Screening tests will yield better outcomes because they detect more slowly growing tumors

questions.text: Of the patients listed below, who would be most likely to benefit from antibiotic prophylaxis to prevent infective endocarditis before a dental procedure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
A 65-year-old man with prosthetic aortic valve 
Indications for prophylaxis of infective endocarditis from transient bacteraemia associated with dental, genitourinary, or gastrointestinal procedures are-
• history of prior infective endocarditis 
• patients with prosthetic heart valves
• patients with unrepaired congenital cyanotic heart disease
• Post cardiac transplant valvopathy
Patients with coarctation of the aorta, repaired VSD, mitral valve prolapse, and aortic stenosis do not require pre- treatment. 
Sterile procedures (ie, cardiac catheterization) and procedures with a very low risk of bacteraemia (ie, endoscopy without biopsy) do not need pre-procedure antibiotics.

questions.text: Which set of findings would be expected in a patient with primary hyperparathyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

↑ urinary phosphate, ↑urinary Ca++

In primary hyperparathyroidism, high plasma levels of PTH increases the formation of 1,25dihydroxy cholecalciferol, which increases the intestinal absorption of calcium. This action of PTH, along with its effects to increase bone resorption and renal calcium reabsorption, leads to hypercalcemia. Because of the increased filtered load of calcium, calcium excretion in urine increases.

High plasma levels of PTH decrease phosphate reabsorption in the PCT, increasing its urinary excretion, leading to fall in plasma phosphate levels.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with multiple ivory- colored patches on back with pigmented borders and the lesion appears bound down and is difficult to pinch. They have been present for months. The likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Morphea (localized scleroderma) presents as plaques a few centimeters in diameter. Hard, somewhat depressed, -white or ivory lesions are seen. They are most common on the trunk but also occur on the extremities. The margins of the areas are generally surrounded by a light violaceous zone or by telangiectasia. Within the patch skin elasticity is lost, and when it is picked up between the thumb and index finger it feels rigid and bound down.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with symptoms of tremor and neck pain. Initial blood tests reveal a free T4 -1.0 ng/dL(normal) and TSH 0.10 mIU/L. Subsequent thyroid function tests 4 weeks later show TSH 70 mIU/L and free T4-0.50 ng/dL(low). Scintigraphy scan shows decrease uptake. What is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Subacute thyroiditis
In subacute thyroiditis, inflammation results in the release of colloid and stored thyroidhormone, resulting in thyrotoxicosis. Damage to follicular cells impairs retention of iodine,resulting in subsequent hypothyroidism and produces the classic picture of a ‘cold’ image on scintigraphy. Management of hypothyroidism resulting from thyroiditis may involve at least temporary replacement with levothyroxine and close monitoring of thyroid function tests.

questions.text:
A 3500 g full-term male infant is delivered by Cesarean section because of breech presentation. He is admitted tc the intensive care unit because of mild respiratory distress. His symptoms resolve by 8 hours of age. Oral feedings progress poorly because of sleepiness and a weak suck Physical examination reveals an appropriately grown infant with hypotonia and subtle dysmoiphic features including almond-shaped eyes and bitemporal wasting. The rest of his examination is normal except his testes are undescended bilaterally. 
What is the most likely diagnosis of the infant in this vignette?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Prader-Willi syndrome 
Hypotonia in the neonate is associated with numerous disorders that exhibit overlapping clinical features. Hyptonic infants often present with respiratory insufficiency and/or feeding difficulty. A prenatal history of decreased fetal movement, polyhydramnios, and breech presentation is common, and some disorders, such as trisomy 21, have recognizable physical examination findings. The infant in this vignette has physical and clinical characteristics consistent with a diagnosis of Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS). Profound hypotonia, excessive sleepiness, and poor sucking ability with consequent feeding difficulty and poor weight gain describe the classic infantile phase of PWS. Physical examination findings in the neonate may include dolichocephaly, bitemporal narrowing, "almond-shaped" palpebral fissures, and a narrow nasal bridge. Muscle size may appear diminished, and the hands and feet may be small.
 Individuals with Angelman syndrome have hypotonia. severe mental deficiency, ataxia and jerky movements similar to a puppet, and are at increased risk for seizures. Facial features include the following: widely-spaced teeth, large mouth, protruding tongue, decreased iris pigment, deep-set eyes, and maxillary hypoplasia.

questions.text: A pregnant woman initially presents for prenatal care at 28 weeks' gestation Upon review of her history, she reports systemic hypertension in her past medical history and medication use of captopril throughout her pregnancy. You counsel her on the potential teratogenic effects of captopril. Of the following, the most likely fetal risk associated with maternal captopril is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (E)
Renal tubular dysgenesis 
Captopril and other angiotension converting enzyme inhibitors pose the greatest risk to the fetus if exposure occurs in 2nd or 3rd  trimester. Teratogenic effects include the following:
•	Renal tubular dysgenesis
•	Hypoplasia of the skull
•	Fetal compression syndrome with limb deformities

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presented with dyspnea 1 week after pyelonephritis episode. She is still on antibiotic treatment. Chest X ray shows these findings. What is the best treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volumes and positive end-expiratory pressure 
Patient has ARDS. This condition is characterized by acute onset of hypoxemia refractory to oxygen administration, poor lung compliance, and pulmonary edema that is noncardiogenic. ARDS is not due to continued bacteraemia or secondary bacterial infection therefore changing antibiotics will not be effective. Though this condition mimics cardiogenic pulmonary edema, pulmonary capillary wedge pressures are not elevated and diuretics are not effective. Corticosteroids are also not effective. The mainstay of treatment is mechanical ventilation with low tidal volumes and PEEP.

questions.text: A healthy 28-year-old woman stands up from the supine position. Moving from supine to standing position causes a transient decrease in arterial pressure that is detected by the arterial baroreceptors located in the carotid sinus and aortic arch. Which of the following cardiovascular changes are NOT likely to be seen in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
increased venous compliance
Fall in arterial pressure decreases the firing rate of the baroreceptors which in turn increases sympathetic activity. Increased sympathetic discharge increases heart rate, strength of cardiac contraction, arteriolar constriction and venoconstriction. Venoconstriction decreases venous compliance, increases the mean systemic filling pressure, venous return and increased cardiac output.

questions.text: A 29-year-old man was admitted to the psychiatric hospital in a paranoid and hostile state. He was diagnosed with chronic paranoid schizophrenia at the age of 23 and had been re-hospitalized four times in the last 2 years, secondary to medication noncompliance. His medical work-up and urine drug screen were negative. During the last hospitalization, he had been stabilized on fluphenazine without any sign of adverse effects. Which of the following treatment would be appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The clinical scenario exemplifies a classic case of non- compliance, which is a problem in many diseases but is especially prominent in psychiatric disorders. The patient responded to neuroleptic therapy but relapsed because of noncompliance. Noncompliant psychotic patients are good candidates for depot drug preparations administered by IM injection every 1 to 2 weeks. Neuroleptic depot preparations are available for fluphenazine, haloperidol, and risperidone. Because fluphenazine was effective and well tolerated, there is no need to switch to another neuroleptic.

choices.text: Attachment of the virus to target cell surface l
Budding and release of a new virus particle
Cleavage of polyproteins by viral encoded enzyme
Entry of the viral core into host cytoplasm

questions.text: Researchers analyze the HIV viral structure and replication cycle for new drug targets. They ﬁnd the virus encodes a large glycoprotein, which gets cleaved into 2 subunits, the surface and transmembrane  subunits. These subunits remain noncovalently bound to each other in the virion. Upon activation of the surface protein, conformational changes occur in the transmembrane subunit exposing the functional inner core. A novel drug is developed that selectively binds and prevents normal functioning of the transmembrane subunit, interfering with the normal viral replication cycle. This agent most likely directly  inhibits which of the following viral processes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Entry of the viral core into host cytoplasm

•	The HIV genome encodes several enzymes and structural proteins in polycistronic mRNAs that are then translated into polyproteins and cleaved by proteases into the individual proteins that compose the virus. 
•	The env gene encodes the polyprotein gp160, which is extensively glycosylated in the endoplasmic reticulum and Golgi body and subsequently cleaved into the mature envelope proteins gp120 and gp41. 
•	These envelope proteins remain associated by noncovalent attachments and form the glycoprotein spikes that pepper the surface of the HIV virus. 
•	gp120 forms the outside surface of the glycoprotein spike and mediates viral attachment to the host cell by binding with the CD4 receptor and a chemokine coreceptor (CXCR4, CCR5) 
•	Drugs that selectively bind gp41 (eg, enfuvirtide) are known as fusion inhibitors because they prevent  gp41 from undergoing the conformational changes necessary for viral fusion, which prevents the HIV genome from entering uninfected cells.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the clinic with an acute febrile illness that developed after an adventure trip in the forest. The patient recalls getting tick bites in the woods but initially had no symptoms. He began experiencing fever, chills, malaise, headache, and myalgia a week after his return. Physical examination shows a diffuse, maculopapular rash; clear oropharynx; normal lung and heart sounds; and mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness. Laboratory testing reveals leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and elevated aminotransferase levels. Microscopic evaluation of the blood demonstrates mulberry-shaped, intracytoplasmic inclusions in monocytes as shown in the image. Which of the following is the most likely pathogen responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Ehrlichiachaffeensis
•	Ehrﬁchiachaffeensis is transmitted to humans by tick bite (eg, lone star tick) and subsequently spreads to tissue rich in mononuclear cells (eg, bone marrow, lymph nodes, liver, spleen), leading to nonspeciﬁc symptoms (eg, fever, chills, myalgia, headache), maculopapular rash, and signiﬁcant laboratory abnormalities (eg, lymphopenia, thrombocytopenia, elevated aminotransferases). 
•	E chaffeensis replicates in membrane-bound vacuoles within the cytoplasm of monocytes and can be visualized on peripheral blood or buffy coat examination as mulberry-shaped, intraleukocyticinclusions(morulae). 
•	Treatment with antibiotics (eg, doxycycline) is usually curative.

questions.text: A 75-year-old diabetic man with Parkinson disease com- plained of worsening of his tremor and rigidity in his arms and legs. Metoclopramide, a prokinetic drug used to treat diabetic gastroparesis, can block dopa- mine D2 receptors in the brain, thus leading to a decreased levodopa effect that explains the worsening of parkinsonian symptoms.

questions.text: A 33 years old multiparous patient has abnormal PAP smear report suggestive of LSIL. questions.text: A patient is diagnosed to have maturity onset diabetes of young (MODY) due to mutation in glucokinase. What will be the management plan of this patient?
questions.solution:

Glucokinase is a pancreatic glucose sensor and patients with glucokinase mutations have an altered set-point for glucose. This results in a slightly high fasting blood glucose but a normal post-prandial response. Therefore, patients with glucokinase MODY generally have stable, mild hyperglycaemia, do not require treatment or monitoring and are at very low risk of developing any diabetes complications.

questions.text: What is the radiotherapy of choice in post operative case of chordoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Proton
Radiation therapy — Tumors involving the skull base are difficult to manage as a result of their proximity to critical neural structures. Maximal surgical resection is the mainstay of therapy, but complete resections are difficult to achieve.
Adjuvant RT is commonly employed, although it has been difficult to administer adequately high doses of radiation with older techniques. 
Conventional two- or three-dimensional RT techniques using photons have a significant risk of damaging the brainstem and cranial nerves, and the lower doses historically used with these techniques have been associated with a high rate of local recurrence and treatment failure. 
High-dose focused radiation delivery techniques with particles (primarily protons) or photons (stereotactic radiosurgery [SRS], stereotactic radiation therapy [SRT], and intensity modulated radiation therapy [IMRT]) have allowed for higher doses of RT to be delivered to the tumor while sparing surrounding structures. 
Proton beam RT is the most widely used charged ion technique. This approach appears to be more effective than earlier use of conventional photon RT with lower doses of radiation. 
Proton therapy demonstrates Bragg’s peak effect.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to the emergency department with 5 hour of substernal chest pain, nausea, and sweating. His ECG is shown in the following figure. Which of the following is most appropriate at this time?

Aspirin, beta-blocker, morphine, primary percutaneous coronary intervention
The ECG shows acute ST-segment elevation in the anterior precordial leads.The symptoms have persisted for only 5 hour, so the patient is a candidate for primary percutaneousintervention (angioplasty and/or stenting) or thrombolytic therapy, depending on the setting. Aspirin325 mg should be given on arrival. Nitroglycerin and morphine are indicated for pain control. Betablockers reduce pain, limit infarct size, and decrease ventricular arrhythmias.There is no role for calcium-channel blockers in this acute setting-short-acting dihydropyridines may increase mortality.

questions.text: Which of the following would result in failure to elicit an action potential in a normal nerve cell in response to a depolarizing stimulus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Blockade of voltage-sensitive Na+ channels
The inability of an excitatory stimulus to initiate an action potential in nerve cells is most likely the result of the blockade of the voltage-sensitive Na+ channels responsible for the generation of an action potential.

questions.text: A 50-year-old Female presented with proximal lower limb weakness for 6 weeks with purplish rash that involves both eyelids. The patient experiences pain while getting up from squatting position. Extra-ocular muscles andother Neurological examination is normal. There is no significant past medical history. What is the best next diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
Creatine Kinase
This patient has dermatomyositis, which typically affects patients aged 40 to
50 who present with progressive proximal myopathy and complain of difficulty arising from chairs,climbing stairs, and getting out of the bathtub. 
Patients with dermatomyositis have the classic heliotrope rash. Gottron papules (red to purple papules over extensor surfaces of joints, especially of the hands) are pathognomonic. 
Almost all patients have an elevated CK.
The electromyography is characteristically abnormal with muscle fibrillations, spontaneous discharges, and sharp waves but non specific.
Muscle biopsy is usually diagnostic. 
High dose oral corticosteroids are the treatment of choice. 
Vitamin B12 deficiency causes distal sensory findings (rather than this patient’s proximal motor findings) and would not account for the heliotrope rash. 
Anti-Jo is specific for Polymyositis. Myasthenia involves EOM commonly.

questions.text: A 56 year old is a known case of alcoholic cirrhosis on treatment. Patient was diagnosed with cirrhosis when he developed jaundice and ascites 2 years back. He is on treatment with furosemide and spironolactone. There is no pedal edema or ascites at present. However, he complaints of dyspnea in the upright position with relief in the supine position. This symptom will be best described as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Platypnea
Dyspnea- uncomfortable awareness of breathing.
Orthopnea-Dyspnea in the Recumbent position.
Platypnea- Dyspnea in the upright position with relief in the supine position.
Platypnea is seen in the cases when increased blood flow aggravates right to left shunting of blood through arteriovenous malformations at the lung bases because of gravity. This condition is typically seen in Hepato-Pulmonary syndrome.
Trepopnea-Dyspnea on lateral decubitus position due to unilateral pleural effusion/fibrosis.

questions.text: Which is the better cut off in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 
 – A
The curve A is nearest to the idealistic point.
Receiver Operator Curve (ROC)
•	X- axis: 1 – Specificity/ FP 
•	Y- axis: Sensitivity/ TP
•	Clinical use: determine cut off
•	Mathematically equivalent to LR for a positive result
•	Types:
–	Straight line at 45o (a): no benefit by this cut off
–	(b) & (c): fair & good results
–	(d): perfect ROC 
•	Excellent
•	100% sensitivity & specificity

questions.text: A 28-yr-old boy presents with digital gangrene for last 4 weeks. On examination the blood pressure is 170/110 mm of Hg and all peripheral pulses were palpable. He gives history of Raynaud’s phenomenon and episodes of Hematuria. He has no fever, cough or hemoptysis. The Renal function test is normal with no dysmorphic RBC or cast in the urine. Antinuclear antibodies, antibody to double stranded DNA and anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody were negative. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Polyarteritisnodosa.
The vascular lesion in classic PAN is a necrotizing inflammation of small and medium-sized muscular arteries. The lesions are segmental and tend to involve bifurcations and branching of arteries. They may spread circumferentially to involve adjacent veins. Fibrinoid necrosis of the vessels leads to thrombosis and infarction of the tissues supplied by the involved vessel. ANA, anti-DS-DNA and ANCA are negative in PAN.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is admitted with fever and breathlessness. He was hospitalized many times for pyogenic infections. Pediatrician evaluated him for recurrent infections and failure to thrive. In the past one year, he has been hospitalized for pneumococcal pneumonia twice and has had 5 episodes of otitis media, requiring placement of tympanostomy tubes. The patient also has a history of prolonged diarrhea caused by Cryptosporidium parvum. Physical examination shows large tonsils, palpable lymph nodes, and hepatosplenomegaly. His HIV status is negative. Pediatrician ordered investigations for further evaluation. It shows that the patient has defective signaling between activated CD4+ T cells and B lymphocytes. Which of the following immunoglobulins likely has the highest serum concentration in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

IgM

• This patients recurrent sinopulmonary and gastrointestinal infections: failure to thrive: and evidence of defective signalling between CD4+ T cells and B cells is consistent with hyperimmunoglobulin M (hyper-lgM) syndrome. 
• Hyper-IgM syndrome results from a defect in class switching in B lymphocytes. 
• Class switching allows B cells to modify production of immunoglobulins from one isotype to another (eg. from lgM to lgA).
• This occurs by splicing out DNA coding for different types of the heavy chain constant region until the desired isotype is reached. The variable region, and therefore the antigenic specificity ofthe antibody: stays the same.
